title: Body-Mind Arts in Context
content: Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen is a movement artist,researcher, educator, therapist, and developerof the Body-Mind Centering® approach tomovement and consciousness. He co-directs theperformance company madhause with Ben Evansand is part of the Portland-based performancesupport group Physical Education (P.E.) withAllie Hankins, keyon gaskin, and Lu Yim.Throwing the Bouquet: Part OneMeasured on a shelf, the full run of Contact Quarterly's printissues--from Vol. 1#1, published in April 1975, through thelast issue, Vol. 44#2, Summer/Fall 2019--amounts to a neat 23.75inches wide.In my imagination, I throw them all up in the air at once, seeingeach individual page, article, sentence, thought, author, dance,drawing, comma deliberation, press run, printer, subscriber--allof it--flying up and apart. It's as if the pressure of holding thesedynamic experiences, flattened together between two covers,standing side by side on a shelf, has finally reached its limit, acritical mass that must explode, transform into another medium,another state.I follow the fountain of pages, CQ 's ultimately untrackable holographicdissemination of embodied dance practice and discovery over thelast 45 years, as the issues unbind and spread out. The aeration isa relief. The dances hover, shimmer, and shift. Gravity hasn't yettaken hold of the bits and brought them back down to earth. Maybeit never will. Maybe new forces are at work here, conditions thatdon't yet have names but do have influence. Maybe our next danceforms, creations, revelations, practices, collaborations, improvisations,breathe a different kind of air, travel best through materials and mediawe haven't yet considered, invented, discovered, or recognized.What you hold in your hands is CQ 's last print periodical publication.Hold it tight. Hold it loose. Savor it. Celebrate its unique 45-year run,in which you have actually played a significant part. Now set it downgently--or enjoy a good hard dash of it to the ground, or just let itfall from your hands and watch gravity take it down. And then comewith us as we shift our editorial weight to CQ Unbound , our year-roundonline publication, and to whatever other adventures come next.In this moment I can feel the familiar thrill of making somethingunfamiliar, the awkwardness and fear and promise of uncertainty,the suspension of belief that allows a new thing to arise, to berecognized and welcomed. We're walking the improvisational talkas we enter this new unknown.I stand in awe of this change. I shift my weight from leg to leg,from land (print) to air (online), not yet certain of the forms thatwill arise to communicate the dancing, thinking, feeling, movementdiscovery, and experiences we will have next.My collaboration with the incomparable brilliance and particularityof Contact Quarterly/Contact Editions codirector and coeditor LisaNelson has been central to CQ over these decades. Together, wehave made manifest the very specific and circumstantial collectionof voices, images, designs, layouts, and formats necessary for CQand Contact Editions. The perpetual friction of our differences hascontinued to irritate, stimulate, and illuminate the passion we havefor encouraging and documenting the articulation of the mysteriesof the moving body. It is one of my life's most unpredictable, precious,challenging, beloved, and valued collaborations.photo by Nancy Stark SmithImprovising at the CQ office, April 2015.And then there's the essential, largely invisible team of brilliantand committed editors and designers that have made the last 20+years of issues possible. Working side by side with me every stepof the way, the designers (Lila Hurwitz, Patrick O'Rourke, and JillApolinario), associate editors (Mary Ramsay, Melinda Buckwalter,Nyx Zierhut, Aretha Aoki, Lailye Weidman, and Meredith Bove), andhardworking CI Newsletter coeditors (Cheryl Pallant, Pen Dale,Sue Lauther, Sara Zolbrod, Neige Christiansen, Dey Summer, andColleen Bartley) have bridged connections between CQ and newgenerations and communities of artists, proofread every commaon the final pages, voiced opinions about page and cover designs,and initiated and followed up on communication with authors. Forpitifully low wages, their commitment and vision have contributedmore to CQ 's legacy than could ever be measured.Right now, I'm picturing the bouquet of issues--with a strongintention of sharing the innovation and inspiration that broughtthem together--unbinding as it flies and, after a long luxurioussuspension, falling in a myriad of delightful ways into your manyunsuspecting hands.With love and profound thanks for your sustained trust andcreative engagement with CQ now, in years past, and in theunknowable and thus infinitely possible future, where ourdancing bodies and minds will continue to meet.Nancy Stark SmithP.S. Part 2 of Throwing the Bouquet (and the original impetusfor that title)--a passing of the Contact Improvisation archivalbaton--will jump the frame of this Note, crossing the bridge toCQ 's online home, CQ Unbound . Read more on our website:Moving Ideas--Physical and Virtual Spaces:CQ & Me & CQ and...I first heard about CQ from Leah Stein in 1994, as anundergraduate student at Swarthmore College [in Swarth-more, PA] when she encouraged us to submit our writingsabout our experiences with CI. It felt exciting to me thata publication would want to hear from college students.I didn't submit in the end, but it was my first exposureto the journal, and I thoroughly enjoyed the articles andespecially the ads and that it was artist led. I noticed theContacts listings in the back of people to reach out towhen traveling, which I did at times.My second significant experience with CQ was in2005, when CQ coeditor Melinda Buckwalter invitedme to write about my project Artifacts of the Ephemeral,which was a residency and installation that took place atChisenhale Dance Space in London, England. The finalarticle, A Moving Installation, appeared in the Place2 issue,CQ Vol. 32.1, Winter/Spring 2007. I was flattered that theeditors wanted to hear about my small project when therewere other, more established artists, and I was also (andstill am) blown away by the attention that the editorialteam gave me in the process of articulating my ideas, theirdesire to understand my practice, and the commitment tohave the writing reflect that, to include details of the feltsense even down to the title.My relationship with CQ changed dramatically whenNancy Stark Smith asked me to be guest coeditor with herof the CQ CI Newsletter in 2012. Our first Skype call wasover six hours long, going over the ins and outs of makingonline and print versions, including photo captions andcredits. We haven't stopped coediting the Newsletter since,and it has developed over the past seven years of our worktogether. The articles have grown in their scope and length.We've improved systems that enable us to edit live onlineand to work remotely. I've had the pleasure to work withVideo still of Colleen Bartley in Walk on Blue, filmed by Richard Bleasdalein 2000 and used as part of Bartley's Meditations on Vulnerability, 2018.the writing from more than 200 authors from about 30countries about their CI practice.It has been a labor of love and a pleasure to workwith dancers and teachers from all over the world who areenthusiastic about CI. I have received an education aboutpublishing, translating, and ways of working with peopleto craft their language (in English) to describe and sharetheir dance practice.I'd like to bookend this story by mentioning my latestperformance at Chisenhale Dance Space in November2018, Meditations on Vulnerability. It is directly related toCQ. I say this because Chisenhale is an artist-led projectthat is about the same age as CQ. It's the place that hasbeen a home to my eclectic practice and has a kinshipwith CI; after Dartington College, Chisenhale is the placein the UK where CI was practiced most abundantly in itsearly years and it supported New Dance and had its ownpublication. It also relates to the approach I take as aneditor, which is directly related to my creative practiceand my experience of living in the world with a humanbody, its form, and its vulnerabilities. Both are artist-ledprojects and both have been a home base for me becauseof a common ethos of curiosity. As an editor, the authorstake the lead and my role is to listen and reflect back andhelp them articulate their ideas in their own unique way.What First Rule of CI?There have been several articles about Contact Improvisa-tion in recent CQs with prominent references to the FirstRule of Contact Improvisation,* most recently How theFirst Rule Brought #MeToo to Contact Improvisation byMichele Beaulieux, CQ Vol. 44.1, Winter/Spring 2019, aswell as Martin Keogh's mention of it in previous CQ articlesand now his book, Dancing Deeper Still. In each case, I havewanted to pipe up to either edit these mentions or footnotethem with my own opinion, but I resisted, as it felt like aninappropriate use of my editorial power with CQ. It isonly now that I have finally taken the time and page spaceto respond. [N.S.S.]*From Richard Kim's blog post: Rules: It's called the FirstRule of CI, or the Only Rule, or...maybe the FundamentalPrinciple. Its shorthand version is 'take care of yourself,' butI've heard it expressed as, 'Above all else, you are responsiblefor yourself.'In my experience as a member of the first grouppracticing Contact Improvisation with Steve Paxton in1972, the original training for Contact and the foundationfor the early years of its development encouraged both anawareness of our own limits and (mostly physical) safety,and, an awareness of those around us. This emphasis onawareness and safety for all continues to be at the founda-tion of my own practice and teaching of CI. The idea oftaking care of yourself--in other words, of dancing withawareness so as to work within your limits (howeverdrawing by Neca Zarvosyou perceive them)--was never a call to be only, or evenprimarily, concerned with one's own safety and well-being.We were always looking out for each other.It seems that perhaps the telephone game phenom-enon is at work here. Apparently some people who heardthe initial suggestion in early CI classes to take care ofyourself and those around you (through the use of periph-eral vision, etc.) were so happy to be given permission toprioritize taking care of themselves that the second half ofthat suggestion/principle withered on the vine. Eventually,it seems, the suggestion was further reduced to take careof yourself first (and foremost) and achieved First Rule ofCI status. Ouch! This hurts me every time I hear it.I wonder when this term first rule emerged. Itcertainly was not there in the first years of CI. Therewere no explicit rules as far as I remember--only anatmosphere and practice of encouraging mutual safety,support, and discovery. (And the suggestion to put onefoot back when catching a hurtling body so you couldspiral on the way down and not just be knocked over.)When I recently brought up this first rule phenome-non with first generation CI dancer Nita Little, she wasstunned and said she had never heard the term before.So I think it's fair to say that this construction is a morerecent invention. It was not there from the beginning,as is regularly implied in exchanges on social media andin writing that I've seen. Exactly when it began, I don'tknow. Although it seems pervasive now among many CIpractitioners and communities, I think it might be usefulfor CI researchers, teachers, and practitioners to knowthat it was not part of the foundation of the work.The phenomenon of this kind of reduction ofvalues, intentions, and suggestions into inaccurate andall-too-solid dogmas and rules is a compelling, albeitdisconcerting, study.I am grateful to feel the current questioning anddiscussion concerning this important but apparentlymisunderstood, misnamed, and misused principle: whichwas, and is, for me always about taking care to dance insuch a way as to not injure yourself or others.I set out to construct a timeline of my involvement withcontact improvisation and Contact Quarterly and was,needless to say, extremely grateful to own an almostcomplete set of back issues--because at my advanced age,I discover that though I can recall places and dates, I amlosing my memory for names. Herewith, what I was ableto pull together:1975: A fledgling dance critic for the Canadian Broadcast-ing Corporation, I'm invited to show up at the VancouverOpera Association for what turns out to be Steve Paxtonand Nancy Stark Smith's first performance of ContactImprovisation in Vancouver, BC. This encounter utterlyupends my sense of what dance might be.1977: I enroll in workshops at Vancouver's Western Front,where I study CI with members of ReUnion (Steve, Nancy,Nita Little, and Curt Siddall), and Mangrove (Curt, ByronBrown, John LeFan, and James Tyler). My first effort atwriting about Contact, broadcast on the CBC in June, istranscribed and reprinted in an early issue of the ContactNewsletter. Later, I travel to Berkeley for the July Projectin the Moving Arts, an intensive involvement with Curt,James, Terry Sendgraff, and Ruth Zaporah.1979: Having moved back to New York and taken a jobrunning the American Dance Guild, I use my vacation toreturn to Vancouver for Current Exchange, a gathering ofexperienced contactors led by Steve and including a veryyoung Stephen Petronio. He heads for New York and a jobas the first male in the Trisha Brown Dance Company.The idea emerges to make improvisation the focus ofthe Guild's next annual meeting...1980...to be held in Minneapolis, Minnesota, in June,with Steve as the keynote speaker; Anna Halprin as theguest of honor; and practically every contact dancer onthe continent involved in a teaching capacity. We call itDance as Art Sport, after a remark by Simone Forti.1982: In a CI class in Manhattan, I tumble off Petronio'sback and bruise my coccyx, convincing myself that it'stime to let this practice go. But by then I've been draftedonto the board of Contact Collaborations, Inc.; I find,tucked in with the back issues, copies of minutes ofboard meetings and a draft book proposal for a fieldguide to contact improvisation, which never material-ized; Cynthia Novack's 1990 Sharing the Dance and other,later treatises--and of course, CQ itself--filled this need.)Novack died in 1996. As I page through my hugecollection of back issues, I become aware of how many ofour colleagues are gone, including James Tyler, my collegeclassmate; dancer and teacher Nancy Topf; choreographerTrisha Brown; and countless dancers and writers whowrote to and in CQ. I was rarely one of those writers, asmy economic situation made it necessary to be paid formy work.From its photocopied beginnings, the magazine grewthicker, fancier, less frequent, but has always been full ofinvaluable material from across the world. Now, in 2019,we bid farewell to this print edition of CQ, as we have toso many other publications. Though I love paging throughold paper copies, digital materials are much more easilysearchable and more widely, quickly, and inexpensivelydistributed. CQ is dead; long live CQ--and the generationsof thinkers, doers, and writers who've contributed to thisunique chronicle.With thanks to Nancy, Lisa Nelson, Steve, and all the restof the crew,In celebration of the digital adventure--CQ becomesaccessible? It is really a new adventure to try and promoteCQ to new readers.Touchdown Dance (TD), a unique company foundedin 1986 at Dartington College in Devon, UK, by Steve Paxtonand Anne Kilcoyne, grew from an idea of Steve's to bringtogether visually impaired and sighted people in theContact Improvisation (CI) experience. It appeared that atouch-based movement method would be of use to touch-based navigators in the world, and an accessible means tobring diverse bodies together. Something extraordinary isseeded by the very idea of CI, and new movement evolves,shapes itself into form spontaneously--like a choreographyof presence, of pause in motion. TD grew into a ground-breaking experience that people travel far and wide to do.Steve and Anne's article on TD [Common Sense]was one of a wave of initiatives that were written about forthe first time in a substantial way in CQ in your Dancingwith Different Populations issue in 1992 [CQ Vol. 17.1].The world of somatic practices, improvised scores, andCI-based methods have been the foundation to Touchdown'sperformances since 1992. Currently, Touchdown Dancehas three visually impaired and two sighted dancersmaking work, dancing CI, and improvising whilst teach-ing around the UK and internationally. We created aneducation pack in which the CI methods and legacy ofSteve and Anne are relayed in word and image to informcommunity and education settings in which we work.We are avid readers and supporters of CQ--and feelrelieved, as it goes digital, that it will be more accessibleto screen reader software and saving trees!!Katy Dymoke; Manchester, UKArtistic director, Touchdown Dance (since 1994)Dear CQ,The transference of movement information through theglobal contact improvisation community--an example:We were fortunate to have a copy of Contact Quarterly,Summer/Fall 2000 (Vol. 25.2), passed on from an elderteacher who had two copies--shared with her keenand developing CI dancer friends in Newcastle, a smallContact community three hours north of Sydney.The article Spacewalk--Reflections on Nancy Topf'sSpacewalk Improvisation was read and reflected on. Howtragically this woman died and yet how wonderful thatshe lives on through her work then and now. Excerptswere read to our dance improvisation collective, andthe exercise interpreted and performed. So playful anddynamic. Thanks, Nancy. And thanks Contact Quarterly.Definitely a journal for moving ideas!Even though it is only the paper version of CQ we aresaying goodbye to, it is still a heart-wrenching goodbyeto the physical, holdable, lie-on-your-bedside-table-able,put-in-your-bag-able, loanable, savorable version of themagazine that has given me, for forty-odd years, a greatbeing to belong to, whose wise, laughing, listening, andloving arms reach around the globe.Even though the online version thrives, lives on,goes out even farther and wider than the beloved paperone, I feel a loss, and a need to express my gratitude forall the years and all the labor that went into making it,sacrificing personal creative time for the benefit of thecollective.Nancy and Lisa, Melinda and all the fabulousassistant and guest editors, designers, and staff over theyears, you have been for me the roots of a magnificent tree,nourishing all of us who wanted to exchange our stories,news, and ideas, add our leaf, our flower, our pine coneloaded with winged seeds, in hopes that the winds mightcarry our feelings far. You gave us access to those winds,lifting us all into the sky on such far-reaching branches,giving all that such great beings give: inspiration, nourish-ment, shelter in the storm, and the very air we breathe. Iam a leaf on that tree, and there is not even a way for meto imagine my life without you.At the Somatics Festival 2019 in Northampton, MA, inSeptember--celebrating the work of Janet Adler, BonnieBainbridge Cohen, Nancy Stark Smith, and the 45-yearHeritage of Contact Quarterly--I sat on a panel titledArchiving the Experience of the Body in Motion withseveral distinguished archive curators.As editor of Currents Journal of the Body-MindCentering Association and Lost & Found: The CUNYPoetics Document Initiative, I felt ready to speak tobeing immersed in people's archives--my grandmother'sbuttons, my father's papers, and, later, the NYC municipalarchives in search of archaeological sites. But it wasn'tuntil I studied Body-Mind Centering that I was able toaccount for my own body and dig back to my earliesttraining, the Rhythms Fundamentals (of Ruth Doing)--a vital, but rare artifact of the American PhysicalCulture Movement.During the panel's closing, Nancy Stark Smithasked how to create an archive that was active, how totranslate experience into language and then open it backinto experience. I get it--the dancer's archive interlopeswith the reader/mover by matter of both light (film) andlanguage (scores, writings, techniques), but dance iscommunal; therefore, even the soloist is derivative from aprevious form or technique. Example: I am currently cata-loguing Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen's papers (1970-present)bound for their archival home. But does the founder's workstand alone? At this panel, Cohen said, This work wascreated in community. She wonders how to house a50-year dialogue that evolved Body-Mind Centering?Librarians and academics must take into account thenature of the bodies of the archive. It becomes a place thatstrikes us in situ and in choir. The archive is an emotionaland tactile experience not unlike the contact improvisa-tion-feeling of profundity of weight, matter, and current(flow). As Nancy put it, the translation of the languageback into experience, and, in Bonnie's words, the work...in community. I call it summoning the interface.Shall we enter the bodies of the archive from theperspective of the mover as well as the language of themovement? Finally, there ought to be a way to fashion amover's papers with enough interface as to allow forour touch.Kate Tarlow Morgan, MA, RSME;Marlboro, VermontI'm mourning the last of CQ's classy print periodicals.Congratulations and best wishes for CQ Unbound (greatname!). With gratitude and love,Aileen Crow was a beloved teacher and prolific somaticresearcher who combined her study and practice of manytechniques and philosophies of movement, creativity, andhealing to transform the lives of her students, colleagues,and anyone who came in contact with her and her work.A Laban Movement Analyst, teacher of the AlexanderTechnique since 1969, and practitioner of Neuro-Linguis-tic Programming, Aileen brought together AuthenticMovement, Mindell's Dreambody Process Work, and amultitude of other bodywork, therapeutic, movement,and creative disciplines to guide people into movement,creativity, and wellness.Her clear writings, playful character drawings,and illuminating insights contributed lucid, embodiedresearch to Contact Quarterly.Paula Sager, cofounding editor of A Moving Journal,writes, Aileen had an eye for rogue movement patterns--the odder the better--and an ear for the unspoken word,the invisible sound. She had a nose for the best of eachmodality she mastered and an unparallel appetite forunfolding process. She was a big-hearted, rebel-mindedcontributing editor for A Moving Journal, engaging con-tinuous, dynamic research and dialogue in the field ofAuthentic Movement.Aileen lived in New City, NY, and was 93 whenshe passed away on April 13, 2019. In additionto CQ's back issues (searchable on our website),Aileen's writings Janis Claxton--an Australian dancer based in Bristol,UK, and then Edinburgh, Scotland--began her artisticand teaching practice with the health and wellness of thebody. Her work shows how art is health and health is artand that art should be enlivening, nourishing, and healing.Her key ideas about relating in contact improvisation wereanchored in a keen sense of somatic health, informed byher deep understanding of the Erick Hawkins work.In leading contact improvisation workshops suchas Dancing in and out of Contact and Returning Hometo the Body, Janis emphasized self-sensing, internalphysics in relation to environment, and detailed alignmentto facilitate students' precise, expressive, and highlytuned dancing. She was highly perceptive and insightfulwith regard to stuck points in one's dancing. Whileworkshopping a skill having to do with partnering, shewould often stop and take us to the floor or to the wallto investigate our own patterning. Working on patternsto release and align the body led to openings and under-standings in the physical, emotional, and mindful aspectsof dancing--often leading to a deeper sense of creativityand self knowledge. Janis was a powerful teacher whocould quickly bring students to their inner truths andto the heart of the matter.Erick Hawkins was a profound inspiration for Janis,and she credits him with the initiation of somatic investiga-tion in the field of modern dance. Janis herself was a tirelessadvocate for healthy dance practice, somatic intelligence,and women in dance. She was strongly critical of thetrends toward extreme bodies in performance. In ourlast conversation, she was enthusiastically checking myfeminist outlook, sharpening my critical thinking, andsharing her amazing energy and insight! I am so gratefulfor her work, artistry, making, and teaching.Tamara Ashley, UKRobin MacRostieApril 16, 1945-September 29, 2019An active and beloved member of the Western Massachusettsarts community, Robin MacRostie brought her creativespirit and passion for dance to everything she did. A long-time member of Dance Generators, an intergenerationaldance company, she was involved in many aspects of artsand activism, and was well-known for her inventive,imaginative approach to problem-solving and communityaction. In addition to studying and performing dance foralmost seven decades, she held a wide range of roles inthe field, including graphic designer, costume designer,dance teacher, and choreographer for all ages, reflectingher vigorous commitment to art making and to hercommunities. Among her many contributions was theestablishment of PreClassic Dance for Children andPanValley Dance, a program to teach and perform IsadoraDuncan dance technique. In 2016, Robin worked at ContactQuarterly as a volunteer, developing the database forContact Quarterly's big library of books and periodicals,which is still in use. Robin embarked on her next greatadventure on Sunday, September 29, 2019. Thank you forever, Steve, for saying Newton forgot tomention how it feels to be the apple. And thank youbeloved CQ bodhisattvas for giving us the articulatedconsciousness of the whole tree, listening to everyapple's individual description of its journey.Love and forever falling, Christie SvaneDear friends at CQ. Wow 45 years! Thank you for all theinformation and connections through the years and for theamazing editing process for articles I have done and for allarticles I've ever read. Blessings in your transition.Much love, Alton Wassonwww.altonwasson.com, www.contemplativedance.orgThank you, Nancy and Lisa, for 45 years of visionary leadership!Bringing together dancers, scholars, and artists worldwide,you've helped create a global movement community we cangrow and nurture together for years to come. What a gift tous all! Love, Susan BauerThank you, CQ, for your unwavering support of research,reflection, teaching practices, and building communities.Here's to your next 45 years!With gratitude, Jennifer KellerTHANK YOU...for your dedication and commitment...for raising discussions and driving our field forward...for your love and passion for dance...for the respectful cooperation...for continuingLet's keep in touch!Rio Rutzinger and the team of the ImPulsTanzIn August 1981 I serendipitously discovered improvisationaldance and CQ at the Vermont Movement Workshop. Each one: I'm here and I recognize that youare here and that we are all here together.NSS: I'm wondering if you give time in your workshops foran open space with little instruction, an open nonverbalmoment for moving or being still, to just process the day'sinformation and experience, integrating the Self and theOther within the day's work.BBC: In my classes, there are no two people who do thesame thing. There are times when I'll just say, OK, this isyour playground; whatever you want to do. Especially nowwhen I'm having such large workshops, I might have twoor three rooms where people can choose a different space.The spaces have their own feeling, their own quality. Somepeople will be dancing; some just lying down; some doinghands-on, giving and receiving individual attention; sometalking, looking at anatomical models, handouts.In the beginning, there's a very strong form, but throughmost of the rest, there's very little form. The theme mightbe comparing and exploring the pubic disc versus thesacrum as the keystone of the arch between the two legsand noticing how the sacrum, as the keystone, locks thespine, and the pubic disc frees the spine. Do it and seehow you feel.NSS: What's interesting to me is that in your work and inthe work you have generated with others, there is a rangefrom very specific anatomical instruction, like what youjust described, to a very wide open place of exploration.Or vice versa. I think that's remarkable and wonderful.BBC: In discussions after an exploration, people will say,I don't know what to say--because it's preverbal. That'sone of our challenges in the field of somatics--how do wecreate verbal and written language. You and Lisa, throughCQ, have been at the forefront of that. How does experiencecome back to words? How do we create a vocabulary ofpreverbal experience that then goes back to the experience?So that the verbal isn't what is being transmitted but rathertransmits back to original experience. It's another seed.BBC: OK. I mentioned earlier the egg and the sperm, theembryology, and I'd like to add something. In the womb,the baby and the mother are one--SelfOther. And thengradually we become separate from the mother, but we'restill identified within the family, within the culture, withinthe era or country. We may or may not be comfortablewith any of these, but we're inescapably influenced bythem. This is our original field in which we experienceand develop our early sense of Self, Other, SelfOther, andSelf and Other. How do I experience and perceive my Self,your Self, ourSelf? How can we gradually grow the accep-tance, discernment, and trust to become comfortable,joyful, and grateful for the multiplicity and diversity ofthe expanding unit?painting by Bonnie Bainbridge CohenAnimals also experience the separateness and the unity ofSelf and Other.Illuminate Theater members Taiwo Ojodun [far background] (Lagos,Nigeria), Olowu Busayo (Lagos), and Jakob Maché (W. Europe) in theirperformance, Olugba (Pure Water), in the Market Square in Bariga,Lagos, Nigeria. The pile of plastic sachets are the common sourceof drinking water for the majority of Lagosians--bottled water is tooexpensive and water from the rivers too polluted. Read Jakob andBusayo's article in the 45.1 CQ CI Newsletter online on CQ's website(public access). Photo © Illuminate Theatre ProductionsToday we're facing this challenge. It's happened atother times in history, but with the Internet we have thepossibility of a unity even if we don't want it. How do we notlose our independent sense of Self, and how do we embracenow the SelfOther with the world itself--including natureand the environment?We're being challenged today at such an enormousscale. There are those who are intensifying the Self ANDOther, and there are those who are advocating for moreSelfOther. And it depends on each of us. How do we helpto build, within a dance, a movement class, or what we'redoing, the recognition of SelfOther within the context ofSelf and Other--the possibility of it through the experienceof it. To point to it isn't enough. There has to be the space,the space for the experience. And then to bring it back intowords so we can think about it, discuss it, and share it, andthen go BACK into the experience. Not to lose our Self andthe recognition of other Selves but to embrace both fully.After we turned the recording off, Bonnie said, Let's breathein and out together. And I said, Can we do it now before wehang up? And she said, I would love to. And we did
summary: Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen is an interdisciplinary artist, researcher, educator, therapist, and developer who has influenced various fields through her work on movement and consciousness. She combines dance, bodywork, yoga, and others with Body-Mind Centering®. Her thesis research involves collaborating with a multidisciplinary team led by Dr. Kitsou Dubois, focusing on the impact of contact improvisation on human awareness.Ray Chung teaches舞蹈, embodying anatomy, and contact improvisation, connecting his passion to other disciplines. His work is a collaborative project that explores innovative approaches for students in the Five Colleges.Toni Craige is an MFA candidate who uses her own research with Kitsou's team on contact improvisation to inspire teaching programs. Her thesis integrates choreography, movement, and philosophy. She plans to lead Somatic Movement courses this semester.Sally Dean practices as a performer, choreographer, teacher, and somatic practitioner across multiple regions. Her collaborative project with the Somatic Movement Project will create immersive experiences for students. Her research focuses on developing psychophysical awareness through performance. She teaches diverse courses at universities including Hampshire College and Duke.Thomas DeFrantz directs SLIPPAGE@Duke:Performance|Culture|Technology, exploring live performances in technology. His work aligns with anti-racist, anti-homophobic, and queer affirming ideals. He also contributes to a permanent installation on the Smithsonian Museum of African American History and Culture.Adam Dipert is a Postdoctoral Research Associate at ASU and Duke/NCSU, focusing on zero-gravity movement and perception. His research explores philosophical implications in cognitive embodied development. He plans to present his findings soon.Kitsou Dubois creates dreamlike works and video installations, experimenting with art across disciplines. She wants to experiment formally, integrating training and creation for collective knowledge. Her work questions the weightlessness of the audience through interdisciplinary approaches.Simone Forti is a dancer who studies improvisation and has written two books. She creates News Animations by weaving movement and words. Margit Galanter develops nature culture projects in the Ohlone Valley, focusing on movement and creative evolution. She promotes collaborative practices for liberation. Sabrina Huth (German) and Ilana Reynolds (Frisian) further explore movement and art, contributing to diverse projects that inspire collective creativity.

title: The Experience of Dulce, Marcela, and Me in Mexico City
content: It is midnight when Dulce, Marcela, and I are headingtoward the Mexico City south station to take a bus toAyotzinapa, Mexico. We meet in the station with a groupof Mexican artists, social workers, psychologists, priests,and social activists who have been offering art, social,and psychological services to people who have sufferedtrauma due to wars, displacement, and political persecu-tion. I don't know most of these people, but instantly I feelsupported by them. We are part of this, and we are in thistogether. That sounds cliché, but the experience is palpable.When the bus passed by Iguala, a town near Ayotzin-apa, I inevitably felt discomfort and fear. In this town, the43 students from the rural teacher-training college RaúlIsidro Burgos were disappeared on September 26, 2014.The reason we came here is to attend the Interna-tional Tribunal of Conscience of Peoples in Movement(ITCPM) in response to an invitation from the NationalLawyers Guild's Task Force on the Americas and theMexican People's Lawyers Society (Asociación Mexicanade Abogados del Pueblo). The ITCPM was created toprovide an opportunity for relatives and victims ofpolitical violence, disappearance, and land displacementin Guerrero, Puebla, and Mexico City to present theircases in tribunal hearings and seek potential legal supportand follow-up from a group of Mexican and internationaljudges. Dulce, Marcela, and I are somatic practitionersand are joined by three psychologists in order to provideemotional support to the participants of the tribunalhearings in Guerrero from August 12 to August 15, 2018.
summary: It's a story about three friends heading towards Mexico City to take a bus to Ayotzinapa. They encounter Mexican artists, social workers, psychologists, priests, and activists, feeling supported by their presence. Upon reaching Iguala, they face the discovery of disappeared students from Raúl Burgos College and their involvement in the International tribunal of Conscience of Peoples in Movement (ITCPM) to defend political violence cases.

title: Somatic Dance and Movement Practices in Mexico
content: Dulce, Marcela, and I have similar backgrounds. Weare Mexican contemporary/modern dancers who becameinterested in somatic approaches to movement, whichled us to obtain training and certifications in Body-MindCentering® (Dulce and Diana) and Feldenkrais (Marcela).The three of us have lived outside Mexico and have gainedfurther knowledge, professional credentials, and experiencein somatic practices, dance, and choreography while livingaway. Nevertheless, the three of us have regular somaticpractices in Mexico.
summary: ... three of us have regular somatic practices in Mexico.

title: Article 4
content: The goal of our presence in the ITCPM was to providea safe and healing container to help all participants (victims,judges, and staff support) recover from the exhaustingexperience of sharing and listening to traumatic eventsduring the hearings. To accomplish that, Dulce and Idesigned the curriculum for the workshops. The objectiveswere as follows:a) To introduce the elements of stillness/action,relaxation/tension, and exertion/recuperation usinga somatic approach, mainly based on Body-MindCentering® (BMC) fundamentals of developmentalmovement proposed by Bonnie Bainbridge Cohenb) To create a positive and playful environment thatsupports participants' relationships, trust, andresilienceIn addition to BMC elements, Marcela introducedFeldenkrais principles. We also used elements of traumaand resilience from the Strozzi Institute and SomaticExperiencing® from Peter Levine.Some of the scores/exercises proposed were awarenessof the front and back body and three dimensions of thebody (length, width, and depth); awareness of the body'ssupports and yielding into the earth; walking awarenessand relation with the space; and transition between stillnessand action supported by prevertebrate developmentalpatterns. We worked with cellular breathing, sponging,and pulsating, which are basic neurocellular patternsof BMC. We emphasized how cellular breathing supportsstillness with presence, and sponging and pulsatingsupport action with awareness of our boundaries andresilience, which prepare us to establish contact withthe space and others.In addition, we were very interested in proposinggroup movement scores that would foster connectionsbetween participants. We found it useful to first useelastic bands as individuals explored the strength andresilience from the extracellular fluid, as well as theregulation of tone, tension, and relaxation. Gradually, weproposed scores with elastic bands and balls in duets andgroups, which created mutual connections, trust, andinterdependency. It was very useful to use the bands as ametaphor for individual and collective resilience and thepower of the collective to address trauma.Marcela, who joined the team close to the conveningof the hearings, introduced elements of the Feldenkraismethod. She offered a lesson about torsions, exploringturning right and left in space while differentiating theparts of the body that can initiate this movement (head,chest, eyes). This lesson fostered coordination as a prepa-ration for the rest of the session. She also conducted ashort lesson on external breathing, which complementedthe BMC experiences of cellular breathing. Each sessionfinished with a playful group exercise, and participantswere invited to share their experiences during the session.

title: Article 5
content: The first workshop took place in the rural teacher-training college Raúl Isidro Burgos in Ayotzinapa, beforethe first tribunal hearing in Guerrero. The other threeworkshops took place in Chilpancingo, where the restof the tribunal hearings were being held.One of the main learning experiences for us was tobe flexible to change and adapt the curriculum of theworkshops to the modifications in the agenda of thetribunals, the number of people available to participate,the time limitations, and the conditions of the spaceswhere the sessions were taking place. After each class,the somatic team met to evaluate the session and planthe necessary modifications in the curriculum for thenext day.The first session in Ayotzinapa was shorter than therest of the sessions, lasting 30 minutes. It was repeated twotimes with different participants, who arrived at varioustimes. The goal was to create a sense of arrival and connec-tion between the participants who had traveled for manyhours. We guided playful and collaborative dynamics, suchas simple breathing and movement patterns repeated inunison by the groups, as well as an activity of passing a hulahoop, which involved collaboration between participants.The sessions in Chilpancingo took place in the after-noon after the tribunal hearings. We offered one and a halfhour sessions, adjusting the time as needed in response todelays and changes in the agenda. We had between 7 and11 participants in each session. Some of them participatedin all three sessions in Chilpancingo, while others attendedonly one. Therefore, we created independent sessions thatfollowed almost the same curriculum but with small varia-tions in each. A few participants had already been exposedto corporeal practices, which was very helpful for theparticipants with less experience, and to us as facilitators.All the participants were adults and included a mixof genders. Most of them presented their cases to the tribu-nal audiences in the morning. They or their relatives werevictims of human rights violations, and some of themwere afraid for their family and their own lives. Otherparticipants were ITCPM staff members, who oversaw thelogistical aspects of the audiences, or artists, communityactivists, lawyers, and national and international judges.Generating a connection at the body level helped todecrease the attention given to differences in education,profession, gender, and the roles that people played at theITCPM. One female judge at the end of a session said:I have been sharing space with you during thelast days, but after this session I have a differentconsciousness about you, and I feel that we haveestablished a connection without words.For other participants, especially those who sharedtheir cases in the hearings, the sessions worked as a spacefor a partial recovery and a playful experience. One femaleparticipant said, I feel calmer now, and I have not laughedin a long time. Another male participant who gave testi-mony in the hearings said, This was a good space, but atthe same time weird....We made collective actions, and atthe same time we dedicated time to each of us.For other participants, the session was a space thatopened body awareness, body-mind connections, andcreativity. A male ITCPM support staff member said:I had the idea that to rest is to stop something, tosleep, or turn off the body, and through this exper-ience, I felt my body in a different way. When Idance or move, I realize that coming back to thecontainer of my body produces a change...such ashaving the possibility to see a problem with adifferent perspective.Three months before the ITCPM, we met with thepsychologists in person and by phone to share the goalsand content of each of our sessions and to find ways to collab-orate and support each other. As somatic practitioners, wefelt supported by the presence of three psychologists, whoprovided one-on-one counseling to those participants inthe hearings who desired it. Participants could choose toparticipate in the somatic group workshops or to receiveindividual psychological support. Some of the participantsin the somatic sessions decided to attend individual coun-seling the next day, and vice versa. The experience waspositive and enriched participants' options to feelemotionally supported during the ITCPM.

title: Article 6
content: For us, the experience was tremendously profoundin terms of what somatic accompaniment means, howto guide it, and participants' responses to it. We wereheartened by the positive reaction of the participants tothe workshops. They were very open to follow our proposal/scores, even when many had not been exposed to thesetypes of movement approaches. We were careful to expressat the beginning that they could choose to stop their parti-cipation in the session at any time if they felt uncomfortablewith it. However, nobody decided to leave. In addition, werealized that touch was something that participants werecomfortable with. They were comfortable holding hands,touching the backs of other participants with their hands,or resting back to back. We were cautious to introducerelations and interdependency, so we started with ballsand elastic bands, and then transitioned into body-to-body relation.We were also very pleased to share this materialin the context of the work of human rights advocacyorganizations. In Mexico, to our knowledge, there havenot been previous instances of using somatic approachesphoto © Asociación Mexicana de Abogados del Pueblo[Left to right] Psychologists from Grupo Cleta (Meztli, Maribel, andGalia), Dulce, Marcela, María Elena Hernández--lawyer and coordi-nator of Asociación Mexicana de Abogados del Pueblo--and Diana.60 CONTACT QUARTERLYWINTER/SPRING 2020photo © Asociación Mexicana de Abogados del PuebloDiana, Dulce, and Marcela with participants of a somatic session using improvisa-tion with bands to promote mutual connections and interdependency with musicalaccompaniment. The International Tribunal of Conscience of Peoples in Movement,Guerrero, Mexico, 2018.in this context. We thanked both organizations (NationalLawyers Guild's Task Force on the Americas, and Asocia-ción Mexicana de Abogados del Pueblo) for their visionaryapproach in convening a multidisciplinary team of art-ists, psychologists, and somatic practitioners to providefavorable conditions for participants in order to help themrecover from the strenuous work of the hearings and theirongoing search for justice. It is worth noting that theseinterventions are not a substitute for the participants'access to justice, the repair of the damage, and restitution.In Mexico, as in most countries, the practice ofsomatic education is predominantly accessible to peoplewho are white mestizo, college educated, urban, and at amedium to high socioeconomic level. Therefore, it felt veryfulfilling for us to share this somatic support with a diversepopulation, including rural and indigenous participants.Following the ITCPM, we identified the need to providespecific workshops to relatives and victims in communi-ties affiliated with advocacy organizations interested incontinuing the somatic accompaniment. We consider itimportant to tailor our workshops with regard to whenparticipants were exposed to the traumatic event and howmuch time has elapsed since. The Asociación Mexicana deAbogados del Pueblo is also interested in continuing andstrengthening the relationship with the team that wasestablished at the ITCPM and, depending on funding,creating similar opportunities in the near future.Since 1990, Kitsou Dubois haspursued the study of movementin zero gravity with a team of dancersand circus artists. Kitsou's credentials,unique in the field of choreography,include collaborations with NASA (viathe French grant Villa Médicis hors-les-murs) and the European Space Agency,and a long-term relationship with theSpace Observatory of the CNES (CentreNational d'Études Spatiales in France).In 1999, she received her doctorate inaesthetics, sciences, and technologiesof art from the University of Paris 8,writing her dissertation on dance inweightless states. Her dance worksexplore alternative relationships togravity, whether on the walls of build-ings, in water, using aerial apparatus,or in weightless environments. To date,she has embarked on twenty-one para-bolic flights and continues to createworks exploring weightlessness.Toni Craige and Adam Dipertare dance and life partners interestedin what humans can learn from zerogravity environments. Adam introducedToni to zero gravity dance through thebook Stardance by Spider and JeanneRobinson, and they have been dream-ing about it together ever since. Toni isa dancer influenced by contact impro-visation and Body-Mind Centering®,while Adam holds a PhD in physicsand is a professional circus performer.Since 2013, Adam's research into zerogravity movement has led him to writecomputer programs simulating thehuman body in weightlessness, speakat conferences around the world, andparticipate in two zero gravity flights.Adam teamed up with Allegra Searle-LeBel (U.S. national coordinator forWorld Space Week) to realize a shareddream: to bring the most experiencedzero gravity dancer, Kitsou Dubois,to the United States to deepen theirstudy of zero gravity movement. Kitsoutrained a group of dancers, includingAdam and Toni, in her work in zerogravity perception during a two-dayresidency hosted by the Smith CollegeDance Department in Northampton,MA. We had no idea how completelywe were about to get our minds blown.--Toni Craige and Adam DipertWho are we without gravity? How dopeople living in a gravitational environ-ment train to move without gravity?What aspects of our intelligence andcapacity can be accessed when we letgo of this primary orientation? Thesequestions and new ones were formedand redefined during our residencywith Kitsou. We found it fascinatingthat a training meant to preparepeople for zero gravity created suchharmony within ourselves on thesurface of the Earth. The feeling ofbuoyancy, ease, and groundednesslasted for weeks. Learning to move inzero gravity challenges fundamentalconcepts that we have about ourselvesand dissolves many habitual behaviorsdeveloped while growing up on thesurface of a planet. Following are someof the key concepts and approachesKitsou shared with us during herresidency.Movement in and out of GravityIn this context, zero gravity (alsoreferred to here as zero g or weight-lessness) is not meant metaphoricallybut literally. Zero gravity refers to thecomplete absence of gravitationaldirectionality. Iconic images of astro-nauts in zero gravity include those oflong hair floating freely in all direc-tions, people velcroed to the wall tosleep, and the use of sophisticatedtechnologies for simple things likedrinking water.To get experience in zero g priorto going into space, NASA astronautstrain on planes that travel in giant62 CONTACT QUARTERLY62 CONTACT QUARTERLYWINTER/SPRING 2020WINTER/SPRING 2020arcs, called parabolas. The parabolascreate thirty-second-long periodsof zero gravity, alternating withperiods of increased gravity. Kitsoureceived a grant in the early 1990s tostudy movement at NASA's JohnsonSpace Center in Houston, Texas, andwas awarded a residency in Londonfor two years (1999-2000) with theagency Arts Catalyst, during whichshe made parabolic flights with theRussian Space Research Agency atStar City in Moscow (a cosmonauttraining center) and with the Euro-pean Space Agency. She has sincebeen on twenty-one parabolic flightswith CNES and created many artisticworks based on her experiences. Herefforts have constructed a new viewof the human body and perceptualexperience released from gravity.The sensation of gravity actingon our mass is one of the primary waysthat we sense movement and theposition of our joints. Kitsou empha-sized that the initial experience inzero gravity is of having no bodyand being only eyes. According toKitsou, our individual lives as wellas the history of our species is aconstruction in relationship togravity, and that the experienceof flight in weightlessness is a veryparadoxical experience.... It's notsimply flying; it's something thatcauses a complete change in yourorganizational reference points.One way to understand the loss ofbodily awareness in zero gravity is toconsider our dependence on gravita-tional references, such as the tensionin our muscles, to develop a sense ofwhere we are in space. Without thisreference, our habituated mappingstrategies become inaccessible. Ofcourse, this zero-gravity-inducedanesthesia presents a challenge toskillful movement in zero gravityenvironments. To reconnect andorient to our environment, we mustfind new strategies for creatinginternal and external relationships.On Earth, we are strongly drawnto organize in relation to the surfacesthat we are touching (for instance,the ground, a chair, or a friend). Inzero g, we can have brief momentsof touching and organizing aroundother objects, but often we aren'ttouching any solid object. The slight-est push off a surface has a very largeimpact on the body. Dancers mustlearn to push and pull precisely andminimally to avoid chaotic, out ofcontrol movement. Kitsou spokeabout our tendency in gravitationalenvironments to spend our timepushing to move forward.... In zerog, you cannot do that anymore, andthat changes everything. She empha-sized the need to focus on supportinstead of only on where we aregoing: We really have to think aboutthe preparation; it's the anchoringthat we have to focus on. We senseda spiritual and cultural criticism inher analysis; we don't know how tobe centered, forgetting our ourselvesand our support in our constantpushing, reaching, and grasping.Kitsou said, On Earth, we spendour time avoiding the act of falling.As dancers, you're very familiar withthis. Because you go toward theground, you try to do so with fluidityand grace. Suddenly, zero g changeseverything because there is no longerany risk of falling. It's not about fall-ing well but about not falling at all.We actually feel safest and most athome when we are falling towardthe Earth. To not be falling is quitedisorienting. Zero gravity trainingshows us how profoundly we areshaped by our home planet and letsus experience what it's like to be afree-falling being, not in the sensethat we are falling freely but in thesense that we are, perhaps for thefirst time, freed from falling.Key Concepts and StrategiesKitsou's training emphasized aquality of quiet, precise centered-ness, with attention to the supportpoint of movement, using the body asa measurement tool, strengtheninginternal connections, and awarenessof the volume of the body and theenvironment.Quiet CenterednessIn the first exercise of the training,Kitsou organized the space like atraditional dance class--studentsspread out, facing the teacher, withbodies aligned to the architectureof the room. We began by standing,establishing our central axis andfeeling the flow or current of gravityin which gravity pulls in a downwarddirection and the earth pushes equallyin an upward direction. Tuning intothese two vertical energetic vectors,our bodies came into alignmentand released excess effort. Next, weadded a third direction by bendingour knees in a simple plié. Instead offocusing on the sensation of bend-ing in the knees, ankles, and hips,Kitsou's verbal cuing created a senseof extension into another spatialdimension with a quality of precisionand a heightened experience ofdistance.In another simple and subtlelesson, Kitsou taught a repatterningexercise for the eyes. She instructedus to turn our head and view theworld from our occiput, instead ofleading with the eyes or chin. Theresults could immediately be felt inour posture, balance, and vantagepoint. She explained that when weinitiate head turning with our eyes orchin, we tend to reach away from ourbase of support and destabilize ouraxis, which has amplified repercus-sions in zero gravity. However, whenwe turn from the occiput, we stay onour axis and see the world withoutleaving our support. The physicalsensation was of rooting the eyesdown to the feet through the path-way of the optic nerve to the backof the skull and through the brainstem, spinal cord, and peripheralnerves, down through the back. Inthis way, we remain calm, allowinglight to bring us information aboutthe world. This exercise alleviates thereach with the eyes, preparing us forzero gravity, in which even the small-est movements can be destabilizing.After establishing this quietlycentered quality, Kitsou asked us toperform simple movements of ourextremities, like lifting and loweringthe shoulders. Our tendency was tofocus on the muscular sensation inthe shoulders and to lose the sensa-tion of the feet and the current ofgravity. Kitsou instructed us to stayconnected to our support and axiswith phrases like keep the memoryof the foot and keep the flow goingfoot to head, head to foot. At first,this emphasis on sensing gravity andverticality felt odd in the context of azero gravity dance training. Later, wecame to realize that the training isabout finding something to organizein reference to while staying internallyaware and connected.Body as a Unit of MeasurementKitsou noted that seeing and turningthe head from the occiput not onlykeeps you centered but makes youaware of the space between yourbody and the point you are lookingat.... It's unconscious, but it sets thebody as a unit of measurement. Shesaid, In weightlessness, the ideais that the body itself is the unit ofmeasurement of the environmentthat you're in. In other words, it'sfrom your own body that you get tounderstand what surrounds you. Forinstance, Kitsou asked us to createcircles with our elbows, focusing noton the muscular sensation in theshoulders (the loudest sensation onEarth) but on the distance from thetip of our elbows to both our axis andour base of support (usually the feet).This strategy of shifting attentionto measurement rather than effortcreated spaciousness in the jointsand structural strength and clarity,while offering a non-gravitationalreference for organization.Strengthening Internal ConnectionsLater in the training, we beganorganizing internally in reference64 CONTACT QUARTERLY64 CONTACT QUARTERLYWINTER/SPRING 2020WINTER/SPRING 2020to forces from various directions.The first exercise in this vein was avariation on the spiraling rolls socommon in release technique andcontact improvisation training.One dancer lies on their back andreaches across their chest with anarm. Another dancer pulls on thearm such that the dancer on the floorspirals onto their belly. If the muscletone is too flaccid or too tense, thepulling dancer has to pull with moreforce. Dancers must create the rightinternal organization for the move-ment to be easy. There is a notion ofdistance and structure in the body,according to Kitsou. If the tone isjust right, it takes almost no effortto turn the body over, and the bodyis almost weightless. She explains,I'm going to give him an intention,but it's not me who pulls; it's whenI sense that he has connected hisspine that I insist a little. It's the twoof us, and at that point, you havealmost no weight.... It's not aboutweight. After establishing an abilityto connect our hand to our centerand move force through the body,we began initiating more complexmovements through the arm, suchas being guided in and out of thefloor and blurring the roles of leaderand follower.Our last session began with anexercise on creating internal connec-tions and a sense of volume. Onepartner stood still, activating thecurrent of gravity. Another partnerplaced a hand on the partner's bodywith the intentions of: (1) feelingthrough the structure into theground, and (2) applying no weightand no force. Both dancers wereto internally connect the point ofcontact to the ground through theirbody. Next, the active partner placedtheir other hand somewhere elseon the receiver. Both partners thenmade a connection between the twopoints of contact and between eachpoint and the ground. Sending infor-mation into structure without weightfelt like a tactile X-ray machine. Itreminded us of contact improvisationexercises, but the weightless handmade the connections on an ener-getic/awareness level rather thanthrough force transmission.Relationships between VolumesIn introducing her material on thefirst day of the workshops, Kitsoudescribed a progression from focus-ing on skeletal organization to theawareness of volume, because, inzero g, we have the sensation of adilation, a feeling of volume, thatwe have much less of on Earth.We are a human volume inside anenvironmental volume. How do wemanage to circulate the relationshipsbetween the different volumes?The main theoretical informa-tion on volume came while doingsit-ups as she spoke about usingvolume to orient the body. Orientingto volume decreases muscular effort!Kitsou had us focus our attentionon the relationship between ourvolume and the volume of space infront of and behind us while doingsit-ups. When we go to the front,we're going to open the space behindus, and when we go to the back, we'llcompress the air behind us.... Beginwith the organization of the body,and then you move on to focus on thespace. It's possible to find your axisbeginning with yourself, but you canalso find your axis starting with thesensation--no, not sensation--withthe awareness of the volume aroundyou. It's the volume around you thatgives the sensation of an interior,and the volume inside that allowsthe volume outside to exist; it's reallya question of constant interactionbetween these volumes. The ideabehind this is that you're never alone,you're linked to the environmentyou're in. Kitsou's choice of aware-ness rather than sensation here isemblematic of many aspects of hertraining. We learned to be aware ofthings that we cannot sense. Is thispossible? It's certainly paradoxical,and we believe we experienced theshift in awareness.Moving Forward with Awarenessand AppreciationSince our training with Kitsou, wehave continued our research intodance, perception, movement, andhuman possibility in zero gravityenvironments through the use ofpools, aerial harnesses, dance stu-dios, flotation chambers, parabolicflight, and other techniques. I noticethat in somatics, choreography,and improvisation, we often involvehuman touch to bring awareness topeople's bodies, but the costume'stouch is underutilized. The costumecan help us enter into the nonverbaland move beyond the visual realms--through the tactile.Somatic Costumes as PerformanceGeneratorsThe costume has a life of itsown. To sense this, I often begin bytouching the costume with my eyesclosed in order to experience thequalities embedded in the material.During improvisations with SomaticCostumes, I have noticed a tendencyfor participants to follow certainaspects of the costume. They mightfollow a sensation, image, or charac-ter (there are infinite possibilities).Where and how they place theirattention in what they follow createsthe aesthetic of the work. For example,if I put two people in the Bin Bagcostume, one person might follow therustling sound of the costume andthe other might explore an expandedbody volume. What a participantfollows creates the relationshipbetween their body/movement andthe costume/material along with thechoreographic material generated.Following is one method of respond-ing to an aspect of the costume thatI have developed into a performancepractice. I specifically use the wordfollowing--a starting place of listeningand receiving--so that the participantdoes not relate to the costume as anobject to manipulate but rather as aco-collaborator in the dance. Thecostume moves you.EpilogueAs I write, I am wearing mySomatic Costume of Lentil Socks,socks filled with dry lentils. I do thisbecause I know it affects how andwhat I write. It's a conscious choice--what Alva Noë calls an action ofperception--along with how I sit onthe chair, the particular chair I sit on,and where the chair is located. I amin relationship.I am choosing these Lentil Sockstoday because once I am at my computer,this relationship affects my eyes. Myeyes reach toward the computer screenand I lose my peripheral focus (ornon-cortical gaze--a way of lookingthat is not about naming, accordingto somatics theorist Hubert Godard).Instead, I accentuate my cortical focusand heighten my concentration in thedirection of producing words, losingthe layers in between. I am writingand seeing at a particular distancejust to the edge of the computer screen.Kinesthetically, my fingers type,creating a particular rhythm andmovement. This frames and createshow I move and what I write.I would like more choice. Thesocks, filled with lentils, respond tothe tiniest of movements; like sand,they shift when I shift. A slight move-ment of a toe, and the lentils respond,adapting to mold around my feet intheir new position. The movement ofthe lentils awakens my feet, creatinga quality of massage with their small,hard, smooth texture. The lentils alsocreate weight in my feet, orientatingthem to their relationship with thefloor.Choosing what I wear is a practiceof embodiment and a return to therelationship between the costume andmy experience of the body. Metaphor-ically and literally, we move each other.This multisensorial, intersubjectiveact of wearing allows me to furtherexperience and understand myselfthrough body, costume, and theenvironment in relationship. Wearingbecomes the bridge to knowing andknowledge, a powerful and untappedsomatic tool in the field of teaching,performance, and choreographicprocess.Relations was a series of performances that took placeNovember 2-3, 2018, as part of the MCA Stage season atthe Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago. Curated andorganized by MCA's Associate Curator of PerformanceTara Aisha Willis, the event brought together Bebe Miller,Ishmael Houston-Jones, and Ralph Lemon for the firsttime as a trio in two improvised performances in theEdlis Neeson Theater.The following text originally appeared in a bookletpublished on the occasion of Relations, which also includedwriting by Claudia La Rocco, titled BebeIshRalph.Sections of the text have been edited and excerptedfor this article.The full booklet is available online as a PDF athttps://mcachicago.org/Calendar/2018/11/Ishmael-Houston-Jones-Ralph-Lemon-Bebe-Miller-Relations.--CQ edsPart family reunion and part-first time encounter, they[Ishmael Houston-Jones, Ralph Lemon, and Bebe Miller]pay homage to their past selves, gesture to the futures ofdance that they have inspired, and testify to their present-tense artistry. These longtime peers, friends, and icons havenot shared a stage since the early 1980s, when Houston-Jonesorganized a series of solo and duet performances highlightingthe then under-discussed intersection of black choreographersmaking non-mainstream dance. After nearly 40 years ofinfluencing each other from afar throughout their prolificcareers, the kinship between Houston-Jones, Lemon, andMiller unfolds in real time on the MCA Stage in two bare-bonesimprovisations that bring together each artist's living,embodied archives and their individual relationships toperforming and making dance.[from the press materials]IntroductionTara Aisha WillisRelations grew from a brief conversation with IshmaelHouston-Jones (b. 1951), both of us exhausted anddowning coffee while I described what I felt was my thennew curatorial responsibility: crafting how the Museumof Contemporary Art Chicago's Stage season influencesthe performance canon, while staying true to my beliefin finding unexpected ways to declare our relationship towhat precedes us. I asked Ishmael how he felt about beingasked frequently to perform his early works or speakabout experimental and improvised dance in downtownNew York in the late 1970s through the 1990s. Was it becausehe is one of the few black dance artists from that sceneand we are in a moment when history and the present are,rightfully, being examined for unconsidered perspectives?I told him that I see him as a forebearer of my practicesas a dancer and curator, among artists including BlondellCummings (1944-2015), Fred Holland (1951-2016), BillT. Jones (b. 1952), Ralph Lemon (b. 1952), Bebe Miller(b. 1950), and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar (b. 1950). Ishmael'sresponse, like his improvisational performance style,was indirect yet practical: You know, I've never actuallyperformed with Ralph and Bebe. I'd love to do that. ForBebe, Ishmael, and Ralph, though the historical andcultural contexts around their work over the last fortyyears require attention, even intervention, more crucialis the present. So, what if the answers to my questionsaren't in a history lesson but a performance? What if theonly way to understand the past is by looking at the artists'bodies at work today? Improvisation is a strategy forperforming and making dances at which these three areexperts, and improvisation has been integral to their workfrom the beginning. Improvisation can be trusted to bringout who they are and what they do--their tics and habits,their past work balanced on each flick of an arm with theimmediacy of responding to the moment. Though they havenever danced as a trio before, since that first conversationwith Ishmael we have all imagined Relations as a reunion.With shared history always just under the surface, theirinventing a dance together in front of an audience iscompletely new yet completely familiar territory....We could mythologize them: Ishmael the punk, forwhom labels like black, queer, or experimental dancearen't limits so much as malleable tools; Bebe the linguist,overlaying multiple articulations of her relationshipto dance, culture, and society, and trusting what thatintricacy unearths; Ralph the double agent, posing big,poetic questions while adroitly dodging answers in favorof something less nameable. But the possibilities withinthese improvised performances on the MCA's stage hingeon the intimacy, often at a distance, of their relationshipswith each other, not on those imagined figures.Among only a few choreographers of their generationand ilk who continue to make work, their relationshipseems as much about mutual artistic influence as it isabout friendship. I have looked to each of them as guide-posts for what dance can be, what choices black artistscan make. We are not starting from scratch in thecurrent dance landscape when we ask big questions byexperimenting with dance, in part because these threehave already been in conversation for a long time, alongwith many others. As Ishmael, Ralph, and Bebe navigatetheir craft together, Relations continues that conversation.EXCERPTS FROM CURATOR'S STATEMENTFOR PLATFORM 2012: PARALLELS,DANSPACE PROJECT, NEW YORK1Ishmael Houston-JonesI chose the name Parallels for the series because while allthe choreographers participating are Black and in someways relate to the rich tradition of Afro-American dance,each has chosen a form outside of that tradition and evenoutside the tradition of mainstream modern dance.... Thisnew generation of Black artists--who exist in the parallelworlds of Black America and of new dance--is producingwork that is richly diverse. [from the program notes forthe original 1982 Parallels events]So it was in 1982 when I was newly arrived in New Yorkfrom Philadelphia where I'd performed with Group MotionMedia Theater (a company led by two former membersof the Mary Wigman ensemble in Berlin) and studiedimprovisation with Terry Fox, African at the Arthur HallAfro-American Dance Ensemble, modern (Horton) withJoan Kerr as well as contact improvisation and onesemester of ballet. I asked Cynthia Hedstrom, the directorof Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery,if I could curate a series composed of a group of Blackchoreographers who were working outside the mainstreamof modern dance. All those definitions seemed so simpleto me then. To me Blacks were the descendants of WestAfricans who were brought to the Americas as slaves inthe 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. They may or may nothave voluntarily intermarried with Native Americans orless voluntarily interbred with the majority population.They were all freed by the end of the 19th century butsuffered discrimination in the form of Jim Crow laws andthe inability to vote or to use the same public facilities oracquire equal education as the majority population. Theycould not marry whomever they wanted, and they sufferedreal violence and death in the struggle to correct theseinequities. They also invented Spirituals, Gospel, Blues,Jazz, and Rap. That's who Black folk were to me then. Idid not consider folks from other parts of the Diaspora:not the Caribbean and no, not Africa.What was beyond the mainstream was somewhattrickier to define. The Judson Dance Theater (1962-64) isusually cited as the watershed moment in dance historywhen traditional concert modern dance gave way to aperiod of more experimental post-modern dance, withMerce Cunningham seen as the intermediary figure.However, most often in the history of the Judson erathe contributions of Black experimentalists are eitherinvisible or relegated to a footnote of the more seriouspost-modern choreographers....In Merrill Brockway's 1980 Dance in America PBS specialBeyond the Mainstream, the only non-white person whoappears in the hour is Kei Takei. Were there no AfricanAmericans working beyond Brockway's mainstream?Ditto for Michael Blackwood's 1981 documentary, MakingDances, featuring the work of Trisha Brown, Meredith Monk,Lucinda Childs, David Gordon, et al. (Blondell Cummingsis seen performing in a clip of Monk's Education of theGirlchild [italics added for emphasis].) This same cast ofchoreographers, with a few variations, shows up in SallyBanes's 1982 book Terpsichore in Sneakers. Apparently,in a dance movement that began in the impassioneddefiant days of the 1960s and proclaimed from the stageand in manifestos that dance was a democratic form foreveryone, everyone was a rather limited concept....It's been thirty years since Blondell Cummings, FredHolland, Rrata Christine Jones, Ralph Lemon, BebeMiller, the late Harry Sheppard, Gus Solomons Jr., and Iperformed on the first Parallels series at Danspace Project[in 1982]. It's been twenty-five since Jawole Willa Jo Zollarjoined us on the Parallels in Black tour to Paris, Geneva,and London. Now Bebe, Gus, Jawole, along with DavidRousseve, Cynthia Oliver, myself, and others, are on thefaculties of major university dance departments. In thefirst Parallels series, I was making the case that to be acontemporary Black dance maker, one did not have tobe a direct descendant of Ailey. We were coming fromCunningham, Nina Weiner, Monk, Contact Improvisation,as well as African and American Black Dance traditions.Now many of those traditions are part of the moderndance canon; dance students have been exposed to thoseforms and to us as teachers....As the African American choreographers of my generationhave continued using their progressive ideas to make newworks and to disrupt the canon, whom can we identify asthe next generation who will wreak havoc on the status quo?ISHMAELRalph LemonShaman. A person regarded as having access to, andinfluence in, the world of good and evil spirits. Typicallysuch people enter a trance state during a ritual, andpractice divination and healing.He shows us his ass, he shows us his dick, his fat, hisskinny, he shows his fear, his rage, he shows us hiswisdom...He's never read Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man; at least hehadn't by 2011.1982. St. Mark's Church, Danspace Project. I meet IshmaelHouston-Jones. What a name, Ishmael, like from Moby Dick,Melville, I think to myself. He calls my dance, Wanda in theAwkward Age, from 1981, a black dance, and I tell himthat that is absurd. He says that it is OK that I disagreeand asks me to be part of an event he is curating atSt. Mark's Danspace, called Parallels. A grouping of an(imagined) black downtown dance community, seven ofus. He was feeling lonely, he said. Sure, why not, I said.and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar are all here. I'm captivatedwatching the whole show from offstage, everybody's verydifferent dancing points of view. Offstage (every night)Ishmael seems to be yawning, or not watching at all. Ican't take my eyes off his dancing. He scares me a little.I don't understand why he dances the way he dances, likehe's mad at somebody, with an odd kind of grace.1987. Rimini (the place where Fellini was born). FredHolland, Ishmael, and I are performing. (I have broughtalong my twelve-year-old daughter, Chelsea, who hascompletely fallen in love with Fred, of course.) Ishmaeldanced tonight in only his underwear and worn-out blackcombat boots, bodysurfing over the empty chairs of thesmall audience in this tidy outdoor plaza, in this quaintItalian port town. I think he frightened the few who werethere. I thought he was crazy.

title: Ishmael Performs at Judson Memorial Church
content: watch Ishmael dance with his mother on TV,PBS, Alive from Off Center, and for a moment I want tobe Ishmael, I want to dance with my mom. Dance yourlittle heart out Chucky, his moms says! Fuck him, I sayto myself, with abandoned envy.1995. Performance Space 122. Tonight I watched Ishmaelcatch flying spit, Keith Hennessy's spit, gobs of it, right inthe center of his mouth, again and again. Like he was inlove, making love. I haven't seen anything as artfullyviolent on stage since then. Just saw the reconstruction of THEM at PS122. Imissed the original version in 1985, probably becauseI was at a Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane show, or maybe MolissaFenley, or maybe a Charlie Moulton extravaganza, thesuperstars at the time. Damn, it was disturbing, vital,poignant, raw, and still timely. In 1985 I was going toballet class every day. Enough said.2011. At Judson Memorial Church, Yvonne Meier (Ishmael'sex of many years back) asked Ishmael to strip naked androll around in a pile of dirt and he did. And then he put ona skirt made of bags of walnuts and she told him to jumpup and down. And he did, for a long time. Which freakedthe dancer-choreographer David Thomson out, me too.I think David was even crying.
