title: Article 8
content: letter to a young artist....My humble advice, because I am older and you areyounger, don't be so self-conscious, vain. What's up withthis generation and its narcissism? It's what's inside, but youalready know this. It's also about getting so deep in the workthat your body disappears. It's about the work, brother, notthe fucking beauty. Making work where you are too confidentin how good, smart, contemporary, transgressive the worklooks--seems--is a mistake.When you start to become too self-conscious, just think ofIshmael, he was inside a fucking garbage bag (unseen) for anhour and it was the best moment of the ten-hour marathonat St. Mark's Danspace (the Parallels redux) in 2012, let'snot forget.Can You See How I See?Bebe MillerHumans are built on memory. We build our place inthe world through how and what we remember. We movethrough the events we encounter according to our habitsand perceptions, ricocheting and navigating through thefamiliar and unfamiliar by way of constant sensory infor-mation. We organize faces, postures, our relation to theweather and the political climate, aligning ourselves tothe interior catalogue of events that we collate andregenerate through the course of our lives.Dances--and dancers--are built by humans. The layersof remembered events we pass through daily become thefascial matrix of the form of the body, the form of an idea,form itself. We remember remembering, and find ourselvesyet again at a point of becoming. Memory is the container;remembering is the action. For me, choreographing seemsto be a way of revisiting small events in some weird,made-up way. I'm less interested in coming up with adifferent ending or turn of circumstance than in thechance to recrystallize a fleeting encounter. I stop timelong enough to read it from the inside, from the flesh, froma distance. I fact-check my attention, choreographically:what's the rhythm, where's the focus, what's the nextmove, what can I interrupt.Watching dancing goes along with making dances.The first time I saw Ralph Lemon dance (in the early1980s?) he was maneuvering a flat cardboard car in theCunningham studio in Westbeth, New York. I think he waswearing glasses. I also wore glasses, but it hadn't occurredto me to dance with them on in front of people. He put onekind of motion next to another (also) in ways that hadn'toccurred to me. I felt a certain relief that he (also) did notseem to be translating a perspective assumed to be forblack people. I enjoyed not knowing why he was doingwhat he was doing. I received it, didn't try to explain it,and kept an eye out for what else he might do. When I firstsaw Ishmael dance (also in the early 1980s) he was wearingan animal; perhaps he was also wearing his combat boots--I can't quite recall. He had worked up an intensely personaland pungent state that was mesmerizing. He moved wildlyand carefully, and there was a hint of Twyla Tharp along-side the bushwhack--pretty terrific. I hadn't seen anyonebecome that transported since dancing during Yorubabembé ceremonies in Queens in the 1960s.My reason for dancing is because of what it feels like.I place one arm in time and space, check it against anawareness forming in another part of my body, note whatI attend to, and proceed to bend, redirect, interrupt thereferences that rise up. I rearrange sensation, image,according to the form that emerges. I follow the timingbetween gestures, the tell, the rise of attention betweenpeople, the toss of their weight, the offhand smirk of ashoulder held in place a bit too long. Dancing holdsmany moments I've walked through before, but it's theirrearrangement rather than the retelling that most interestsme. What I remember, what I carry with me, is what Imeasure the present moment against.Earlier in my career, when I began to realize thatpeople were paying attention to these dances we weremaking and coming back more than once to see what Iwas up to (even though I wasn't sure what I was up to),I was regularly asked about what perspective on theAfrican diaspora I was sharing. Clearly my tellingneeded some translating. How to answer that?Elaine Summers (1925-2014) was achoreographer and founding memberof the Judson Dance Theater. Her perfor-mance work was presented at the Museumof Modern Art and the GuggenheimMuseum, at the Lincoln Center Out ofDoors festival, and throughout the world.She was founding director of severalorganizations, including the ElaineSummers Dance & Film Company, theExperimental Intermedia Foundation,and the Kinetic Awareness Center.In the 1970s, she began developingand teaching Kinetic Awareness® (KA), anapproach to somatic education with broadapplications for both performing artistsand the general public. KA includes avariety of awareness-based techniques,such as placing rubber balls under variousparts of the body to provide contact withinner sensations. Practitioners of KA exper-ience enhanced awareness of inefficientmovement patterns and psycho-physicalpatterning, creating space for healing,change, and choice. KA was the basisof training for dancers in Summers'sexuberant intermedia projects.I imagine that each person whoworked closely with Elaine Summershas their own version of her. In mymemories of Elaine, she is a guideleading her students toward innerrealms, where, like archaeologistson a dig, we explore in fine detail themysteries of our bodies. In her role asguide, she is free of all agendas savea generous, listening presence. Sheexudes a deep respect for our unique-ness as individuals, sitting besideand supporting us as we delve intothe aliveness of our moving bodies.Through her words and quality ofpresence, she guides us in a practiceof noticing: our emotions, memories,and the evolution of ideas withinour flesh.As I write about Elaine, I becomeentangled with my former self. ThoughI worked with her intimately from1978 to 1983 and beyond, I did notknow Elaine like she knew me. In ourtime together, the relationship wasalways about me. I trusted her com-pletely, and because of this, I learnedto trust the truth of my body, senses,and movement.When I began working withElaine, I was hungry: a young,searching artist yearning to createoriginal work. I was also in physicaland psychological pain. My kneeshad been swelling regularly sinceadolescence (I was put on pointesince age 8), and I had suffered lower-back and shoulder blade pain since1974. Emotionally, I was strugglingwith issues of self-worth tied topersonal, gender, and cultural historyas a Puerto Rican woman, and I wason a quest to decolonize my body/mind/psyche from assumptions andpatterns (subconscious/habitual)of thinking, being, and moving thatblocked inner knowledge. Elaine'sprocess of Kinetic Awareness per-fectly matched my needs. It meldedsystematic study and training of thebody with artistic praxis, teachingme how to develop my artistry whilesimultaneously healing physical andpsychological wounds. While workingwith her, my repertoire of movementexpanded exponentially as I investi-gated embodied phenomena such asbody image, frozen tension--twoof several names Elaine used to referto particular psycho-physical states--and inefficient movement patternsarising from various emotional states.Kinetic Awareness and improvisationbecame central practices in my questto develop movement forms thatwould express my reality as a PuertoRican woman.Elaine's approach empoweredme as an artist because it allowedme to integrate healing into mycreative practice. Kinetic Awarenessinitiated me into breathwork andsomatic awareness practices thatbecame entry points to the energeticdimensions of my body. This was myintroduction into mindful movementas a basis for cultivating the wholeself, including personal, anatomical,physiological, psychological, chemical,electrical, and spiritual dimensions.Kinetic Awareness and improvisationbecame tools for accessing my bodyas teacher and healer and for harness-ing the wild complexity of mindfulembodiment within a life in dance.I first met Elaine in 1978 as aCETA1 dancer with the Cultural CouncilFoundation. I had been assigned to dancewith her in a series of performances ofher work Illuminated Workingman (1974),which took place in NYC parks. Therewere several other CETA dancers, andI remember the performing experiencewas unlike any I had had until then.While Elaine was wildly enthusiastic,her process was chaotic. She wouldchange unison movement for a largegroup section moments before theshow, leaving dancers confused andunable to achieve the intended unison.But it was enormously fun. One of herdancers, Tedrián Chizik--a performerThe studio is a large open space, with white walls and nowindows. There are containers with balls and large blocks of foamcovered with faux fur blankets. Grab a blanket from a pile, and one ormore balls, find a spot on the floor and lie down. Close your eyes andbreathe, sensing into the body changes as you drop your weight ontoa ball, letting go. Scanning through your body, each breath bringsmore and more sensations into awareness. Sensing your weightcontouring around the balls, how much of your whole self canyou feel--the joints, bones, pulse, breath, muscles, skin? Play withsounding the breath, allowing/sensing the vibration of the soundand breath to reverberate through your tissues, sensing this particularrelationship of body parts in space, release into gravity. The chorus ofsounds and dancers moving ever so slowly on the ground supportsthe process.Elaine makes her way around the room addressing eachstudent: What are you working on? She gives you her completeattention, making suggestions for how to work toward a particulargoal--find articulation in the lower back, release tension in theshoulder, connect through the legs, etc. After 30 to 45 minutes ofworking individually, we transition into working on letting the bodystretch itself, a practice of following minute impulses in and throughthe body to move into extension. What does it mean to let go? Tofollow the body's impulses? We always start slowly, deliberately,articulating and becoming aware of every body part's engagement,Dancing with Elaine (cont'd)using as little tension as possible. Adding extension tension takesus into release, which brings speed, momentum. We let the pulsingenergies and rhythms of extension and release move us throughlevels, space, and working with each other. In between extendingand releasing, leading and following, we experience being dancedby forces of movement, sound, and weight. Surrendering to themovement and the moment, the energy builds. The body and voiceare freed. I experience kinesthetic and aesthetic delight, surprise,freedom, and connection. Healing.Sometimes the experience is slow, dark, emotional. You closeyour eyes and tune into your sadness, anger, pain, or fear of lettinggo. Breathing and moving ever so slowly and attentively, I realizethat I am able to release a bit of this, one breath at a time, or throughthe sounds I am making. Elaine encourages us to stay with whatevercomes up--emotional release and expression are an integral partof the quest, mission, or commitment to creating dance art andbecoming fully human. We practice allowing emotions to movethrough us; attentively aligning layers of experience (movement,shape, emotion, sound), we engage in their artistic expression. It'sOK to cry as long as you keep working. In this process of embracingpainful feelings, I discover that they no longer cripple me but, in fact,help me grow, fuel the work. Healing.In private sessions, we worked with light and color. In thisenergetic/spiritual work, she would ask me to close my eyes andsense my pulse or my breath, and then to describe the experience.If I reported sensations of rhythm, color, and light, she instructedme to breathe into the experience, give into it, and direct it to thethird eye or brain--an initiation into light work, expandingpossibilities. Healing.uand children's theater director whohad studied and danced with Elainefor many years--extolled the depthand transformative power of her work,which persuaded me to study with heras a way to heal my aching body.Elaine was, first and foremost,an artist. She applied her artisticphilosophy, burnished in 1960s experi-mentalism, to investigations of thebody and movement. Prior to myworking with her, she had been activein generating democratizing ideas andforms as a member of the Judson DanceTheater.2 She was a strong advocate forwhat she called the rainbow range ofmovement possibilities and aesthetics.The ethos of her kinesthetic investi-gations echoed Judson peer YvonneRainer's manifesto that no one thingis any more important than any other.3Elaine privileged no single way ofmoving over another, nor did sheconsider any body part to be moreimportant than another. This commit-ment to a democratic view of the bodyled her to explore diverse approaches topresenting bodies both through liveperformance and on film. Beginningin the 1960s, she worked freely acrossmedia, and in 1968 she founded theExperimental Intermedia Foundation,which is still active today.In her Kinetic Awareness anddance improvisation classes in thelate '70s and '80s, Elaine regularlyposed the question, How does yourbody (head, hip, shoulder) want tomove? For me, a dancer trainedin old-style pedagogies of classicaldance requiring students to move inways designed by others, Elaine'squestion presented a revolutionaryproposal that both baffled anddelighted me while opening up newpossibilities for creative experimenta-tion. I experienced it as an invitationfor me to enter the singular kineticconsciousness of my unique body.Elaine encouraged us to observe,without judgment, the experienceof our bodies moving of their ownvolition. We understood that in KineticAwareness, the mind's job was todirect the body to move and observeits corporeal unfolding. This practice,like phenomenological and Buddhistpractices I would encounter laterin my career, demanded sustainedattention to present space/time,supported by the suspension ofpreconceptions and judgments.How Does This Body Want toMove?In 2016, I initiated the projectHow Does This Body Want to Move?--a multimodal performance andresearch initiative that served as areflection on Elaine's legacy andinfluence on me. This intensive projectentailed a year of performances,master classes, and public conver-sations relating to Elaine's oeuvre,which culminated in the performanceof Elaine in the air and me, a programof works choreographed by myself,Patti Bradshaw, Marion Ramírez, andNoemí Segarra, presented at the 92ndStreet Y in NYC. While conductingmovement research for this project,I discovered that the act of dancingbrought Elaine vividly back to lifein my consciousness. As I danced inrehearsals and performances, shevisited in flashes and fragments,seeding new awareness of herinfluence on my choreography andteaching over the decades. I offerselect fragments here as a means ofrepresenting the way her memoryreverberates in my dancing. Thefollowing two sections containconcepts, reflections, quotes, andmemories culled from movementresearch, conversations with peers,and notes I took while studying withElaine and working on How Does ThisBody Want to Move?In Elaine's Words: Notes fromKinetic Awareness Journals1978-1983Start as tiny as possible: discoverthe subtlety of your body.Center is the place where the bodyreturns when you are not doinganything.There is no place in this work forcriticism.Understand your own body--learnyour problem areas, what's strong,what needs help--and confrontAunt Matilda [the negative voicesfrom the past].The body is an electrical field; energybubbles inside. We may perceive theroom or objects in the room vibrating,48 CONTACT QUARTERLY SUMMER/FALL 2019but somehow this is considered notnormal in average adults. We aretrained not to see, not to feel, and it isfrightening when we experience it.Allow both the conscious andunconscious to manifest themselves.The function of the intellectual mindis to observe.One achieves control throughletting go.Remembering Elaine Today2018One could say that Elaine's danceclass was a workshop in phenomeno-logical methodology. When exploringa body part or way of moving, sheencouraged us to move as if we hadnever moved that part of the bodybefore. As we explored our individ-ual experiences, we reinforced eachother's practices, will, and creativitythrough our own example. PattiBradshaw remembers: We became somuch our own movers that we wouldjoke that she had ruined us to be ableto dance with anyone else. One dayyou found out that you knew how todance in your own way, and you hadthe skills to develop in whatever wayyou liked.Marion Ramírez, who studiedwith Elaine from 2003 to 2010, remem-bers that Elaine taught us that wewere experts of our own bodies.This aspect of the teachings was pro-foundly significant to me given myprior training in classical Europeandance, and it was especially importantin my decolonization quest as aPuerto Rican woman.Elaine's generosity and care forher students knew no bounds. Shesupported my artistic developmentwell beyond my participation inher classes and performances. Forinstance, while I was her student, sheonce lent me her loft studio for anearly self-produced concert of work.Over subsequent years, she attendedmany of my concerts, includingseveral in the South Bronx, an areathat most Manhattan folks refused totravel to in order to see work. I havemany memories of her at the end ofeach show, limping down the aisle,beaming a smile, and carrying flowers,like a fairy godmother imparting herblessing. I always wondered how shegot there.Elaine's approach to time wasradical. Marion recalls that in herclasses, there was no need to getanywhere or achieve anything, norto fulfill any expectations. Workingslowly for extended periods of time,you become aware of the flexiblenature of time.
